The Women (2008)

  • T-Meter Critics
  • Top Critics
  • RT Community
  • My Critics
  • My Friends
10 %
Tomatometer

How does the Tomatometer work

Reviews Counted: 119

Fresh: 12

Rotten:107

Average Rating: 3.7/10

Consensus: The Women is a toothless remake of the 1939 classic, lacking the charm, wit and compelling protagonists of the original.

Rated: PG-13 [See Full Rating] for sex-related material, language, some drug use and brief smoking

Genre: Comedies

Theatrical Release: Sep 12, 2008 Wide

Box Office: $19,321,011

Synopsis: What happens when you combine a brilliant, all-female, all-star cast, headed by Meg Ryan and Annette Bening; celebrated comedy writer/director/producer Diane English (“Murphy Brown”); and a classic story about a circle of New York... What happens when you combine a brilliant, all-female, all-star cast, headed by Meg Ryan and Annette Bening; celebrated comedy writer/director/producer Diane English (“Murphy Brown”); and a classic story about a circle of New York friends? The answer is THE WOMEN, a smart, sparkling comedy about contemporary womanhood and the power of female relationships. Based on George Cukor’s 1939 film and Clare Boothe Luce’s 1936 stage play, THE WOMEN whisks us into a busy pocket of Manhattan society, where the publishing, fashion and finance industries play. At the center of the tale is Ryan’s character, Mary Haines, a thoroughly modern woman suddenly confronted with an age-old dilemma: a cheating husband. The ladies in her life swiftly rally to Mary’s side, led by her best friend, Sylvie Fowler, a dynamic magazine editor played by Bening. But when Sylvie betrays Mary in a Faustian bargain, the entire group is shaken to the core – and two women face the most painful breakup of all - their friendship. --© Picturehouse [More]

Starring: Meg Ryan, Annette Bening, Eva Mendes, Debra Messing

Starring: Meg Ryan, Annette Bening, Eva Mendes, Debra Messing, Jada Pinkett Smith, Candice Bergen, Carrie Fisher, Lynn Whitfield, Joanna Gleason, Ana Gasteyer, Debi Mazar, Bette Midler, Cloris Leachman

Director: Diane English

Director: Diane English
Screenwriter: Diane English
Producer: Victoria Pearman, Mick Jagger, Bill Johnson, Diane English
Composer: Mark Isham
Studio: Picturehouse

[See More Credits]

Not nearly as bad as I thought...but that's not saying much.

Full Review | Comment
09/20/08
Charles Koplinski
Illinois Times

The most disappointing aspect of The Women is how few laughs it delivers.

Full Review | Comment
09/19/08
Sarah Boslaugh
Playback:stl

It takes ovaries the size of Alaska to update a classic like George Cukor's 1939 catfight "The Women," but that's just what Diane English has done--and nobody should thank her for it.

Full Review | Comment
09/18/08
Christopher Smith
Bangor Daily News (Maine)

No barbs, no bite, no passion; the claws stay sheathed and the film stays bland

Full Review | Comment
09/18/08
Jackie K. Cooper
jackiekcooper.com

They say that you can never have too much of a good thing, but in this case, there's so much talent and only so much time that most of the actresses are wasted in cameo roles.

Full Review | Comment
09/17/08
Sean McBride
Sean the Movie Guy

A wrongheaded, glossy mediocrity -- a perfect companion piece to the summer's earlier offerings of Sex and the City and Mamma Mia!.

Full Review | Comment
09/17/08
Ken Hanke
Mountain Xpress (Asheville, NC)

Fans of the original should alter their expectations while those who haven't experienced the verbal sparring between Russell, Crawford, Mary Boland, et al, should take in this new version first, if only to give it a fair shake.

Full Review | Comment
09/16/08
Richard Knight
Windy City Times

While there are many ways in which it falls short of its predecessor the fact that it possesses, arguably, a more retrograde view of gender roles...is probably the most depressing.

Full Review | Comment
09/16/08
Tim Brayton
Antagony & Ecstasy

There is no need for this film.

Full Review | Comment
09/16/08
Linda Cook
Quad City Times (Davenport, IA)

Shame on English for wasting an opportunity to make a modern-day classic.

Full Review | Comment
09/16/08
Jeanne Kaplan
Kaplan vs. Kaplan

You'll be looking at your watch for a merciful end.

Full Review | Comment
09/16/08
David Kaplan
Kaplan vs. Kaplan

The funniest thing about The Women is that Mick Jagger is one of the producers. There was a knowing laugh in the theatre as his name sprang up in the opening credits -- our last chance to laugh, as it turned out, for the next two hours.

Full Review | Comment
09/15/08
Anthony Lane
New Yorker
Top Critic

This can't be what women want to watch. A film written, directed and starring all women completely misses the mark of embracing strong powerful independent women.

Full Review | Comment
09/15/08
Jeff Bayer
The Scorecard Review

First time filmmaker Diane English (Murphy Brown) labored for over a decade to bring this project to the screen, but passion shouldn't be confused with vision.

Full Review | Comment
09/14/08
Geoff Berkshire
Metromix.com

'The Women' entertained me much more than I expected it would, especially after seeing those dreadful previews.

Full Review | 2 Comments
09/13/08
Betty Jo Tucker
ReelTalk Movie Reviews

Trite and boring portrait of rich and self-absorbed women.

Full Review | Comment
09/13/08
Frederic and Mary Ann Brussat
Spirituality and Practice

Lame and saturated in the dour makeup of an afternoon soap opera, The Women is a transparent chick flick standing on its shaky high heels without much support.

Full Review | Comment
09/13/08
Frank Ochieng
Movie Eye

It seems like cinematic sacrilege to compare Diane English's disappointing contemporary drivel with George Cukor's still-hilarious 1939 original.

Full Review | Comment
09/13/08
Susan Granger
SSG Syndicate

Good performances and stylish direction can't disguise what The Women really is: a throwback to a simpler time when women were simple and everyone was happy about it

Full Review | Comment
09/12/08
Andrea Chase
Killer Movie Reviews

The picture's 14-year path to fruition should have taken a fifteenth in order to get the kinks in the script worked out.

Full Review | Comment
09/12/08
